                                enough for her palate. The great fault of the Greek wines was their
                                tartness, for which reason sea-water was mixed with them all except
                                the Chian, which was the highest class of wine.

: "Pater," literally
                                "father;" a title by which the young generally addressed aged
                                persons who were strangers to them.

lemma.#text: All the casks, all the vessels

note.#text:
:
                                "Dolia omnia, omnes serias." The finer kinds of wine were drawn off
                                from the " dolia," or large vessels, into the "amphorae," which,
                                like the "dolia," were made of earth, and sometimes of glass. The
                                mouths of the vessels were stopped tight by a plug of wood or cork,
                                which was made impervious to the atmosphere by being rubbed over
                                with a composition of pitch, clay, wax, or gypsum. On the outside,
                                the title of the wine was painted, and among the Romans the date of
                                the vintage was denoted by the names of the Consuls then in office.
                                When the vessels were of glass, small tickets or labels, called
                                "pittacia," were suspended from them, stating to a similar effect.
                                The "seriae" were much the same as the "dolia," perhaps somewhat
                                smaller; they were both long, bell-mouthed vessels of earthen-ware,
                                formed of the best clay, and lined with pitch while hot from the
                                furnace. "Seriae" were also used to contain oil and other liquids;
                                and in the Captivi of Plautus the word is applied to pans used for
                                the purpose of salting meat. "Relino" signifies the act of taking
                                the seal of pitch or Wax off the stopper of the
                            wine-vessel.

p.#text:
Is she, do you ask? I have felt it; for 1 have given her and her retinue
                            one dinner; had I to give them another such, it would be all over with
                            me; for, to pass by other matters, what a quantity of wine she did
                            consume for me in tasting only, saying thus, "This wine is too acid, respected
                                sir, do please look for
                            something more mellow." I opened all the casks, all the
                                vessels;" she kept all on the stir: and this but a single
                            night. What do you suppose will become of you when they are constantly
                            preying upon you? So may the Gods prosper me, Menedemus, I do pity your
                            lot.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Let him do what he will; let him take, waste, and squander; I'm
                            determined to endure it, so long as I only have him with me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
If it is your determination thus to act, I hold it to be of very great
                            foment that he should not be aware that with a full knowledge you grant
                            him this.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What shall I do ?

note.#text: : Dromo.

:
                                "Fenestram ;" literally, "a window."

p.#text:
Any thing, rather than what you are thinking of; supply him with money
                            through some other person; suffer yourself to be imposed upon by the
                            artifices of his servant: although I have smelt out this too, that they
                            are about that, and are secretly planning it among them. Syrus is always
                            whispering with that servant of yours; they impart their plans to the
                            young men; and it were better for you to lose a talent this way, than a
                            mina the other. The money is not the question now, but this--in what way
                            we can supply it to the young man with the least danger. For if he once
                            knows the state of your feelings, that you would sooner part with your
                            life, and sooner with all your money, than allow your son to leave you;
                            whew ! what an inlet will you be opening for
                            his debauchery! aye, and so much so, that henceforth to live can not be
                            desirable to you. For we all become worse through indulgence. Whatever
                            comes into his head, he'll be wishing for; nor will he reflect whether
                            that which he desires is right or wrong. You will not be able to endure
                            your estate and him going to ruin. You will refuse to supply him: he
                            will immediately have recourse to the means by which he finds that he
                            has the greatest hold upon you, and threaten that he will immediately
                            leave you.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: You seem to speak the truth, and just what is the fact.

note.#text:
: Colman has the
                                following Note here: "Hedelin obstinately contends from this
                                passage, that neither Chremes nor any of his family went to bed the
                                whole night; the contrary of which is evident, as Menage observes,
                                from the two next Scenes. For why should Syrus take notice of his
                                being up so early, if he had never retired to rest? Or would Chremes
                                have reproached Clitipho for his behavior the night before, had the
                                feast never been interrupted? Eugraphius's interpretation of these
                                words is natural and obvious, who explains them to signify that the
                                anxiety of Chremes to restore Clinia to Menedemus broke his
                                rest."

p.#text:
I'faith, I have not been sensible of sleep this night with my
                                eyes, for thinking of this--how to restore your son to you.

Give me your right hand. I request that
                            you will still act in a like manner, Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I am ready to serve you.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Do you know what it is I now want you to do?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
As you have perceived that they are laying a plan to deceive me, that
                            they may hasten to complete it. I long to give him whatever he wants: I
                            am now longing to behold him.

p.#text:
I'll lend my endeavors. This little business is in my way. Our neighbors
                            Simus and Crito are disputing here about boundaries; they have chosen me
                            for arbitrator. I'll go and tell them that I can not possibly give them
                            my attention to-day as I had stated I would. I'll be here immediately.

Pray do.  Ye Gods, by our trust in you! That
                            the nature of all men should be so constituted, that they can see and
                            judge of other men's affairs better than their own! Is it because in our
                            own concerns we are biased either with joy or grief in too great a
                            degree How much wiser now is he for me, than I have been for myself!

note.#text:
: Madame Dacier observes that Chremes seizes
                                this as a very plausible and necessary pretense to engage Menedemus
                                to return home, and not to his labors in the field, as he had at
                                first intended.

p.#text:
I have disengaged myself, that I might lend you my services at my
                            leisure. Syrus must be found and instructed by me in this business. Some
                            one, I know not who, is coming out of my house: do you step hence home,
                            that they may not perceive that we are conferring together.

div2.stage: Enter SYRUS from the house of CHREMES.

p.#text:
Run to and fro in every direction;
                            still, money, you must be found: a trap must be laid for the old man.
Who's that speaking?  I'm undone! Did he hear it, I wonder?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Syrus.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Well----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
All right. Really, I am quite surprised at you, Chremes, up so early,
                            after drinking so much yesterday.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Not too much.

note.#text:
: This was a
                                proverbial expression, signifying a hale and vigorous old age. It
                                has been suggested, too, that it alludes to the practice of some old
                                men, who drink more than they eat. It was vulgarly said that eagles
                                never die of old age, and that when, by reason of their beaks
                                growing inward, they are unable to feed upon their prey, they live
                                by sucking the blood.

p.#text:
Not too much, say you? Really, you've seen the old age of an
                                eagle, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Pooh, pooh!

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: A pleasant and agreeable woman this Courtesan.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, so she seemed to me, in fact.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: And really of handsome appearance.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Well enough.

lemma.#text:
Not like those of former
                                    days

note.#text:
: Syrus, by showing himself an admirer of the good
                                old times, a " laudator temporis acti," is wishful to flatter the
                                vanity of Chremes, as it is a feeling common to old age, perhaps by
                                no means an unamiable one, to think former times better than the
                                present. Aged people feel grateful to those happy hours when their
                                hopes were bright, and every thing was viewed from the sunny side of
                                life.

p.#text:
Not like those of former days, but as times are now, very passable: nor do I in the
                            least wonder that Clinia doats upon her. But he has a father--a certain
                            covetous, miserable, and niggardly person--this neighbor of ours
                                . Do you know him ? Yet, as if
                            he was not abounding in wealth, his son ran away through want. Are you
                            aware that it is the fact, as I am saying ?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How should I not be aware? A fellow that deserves the mill.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That servant of the young gentleman, I mean.

p.#text: Syrus! I was sadly afraid for you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To suffer it to come to this!

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What was he to do?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Do you ask the question? He ought to have found some expedient,
                            contrived some stratagem, by means of which there might have been
                            something for the young man to give to his mistress, and thus have saved
                            this crabbed old fellow in spite of himself.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: You are surely joking.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: This ought to have been done by him, Syrus.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: How now--pray, do you commend servants, who deceive their masters?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Upon occasion--I certainly do commend them.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Inasmuch as it often is the remedy for great disturbances. Then would
                            this man's only son have staid at home.

p.#text:
Whether he says this in jest or in earnest, I
                            don't know; only, in fact, that he gives me additional zest for longing
                            still more to trick him.

lemma.#text:
Can no longer support her
                                expenses

note.#text: : He refers to Menedemus and Bacchis.

p.#text:
And what is he now waiting for, Syrus? Is it until his father drives him
                            away from here a second time, when he can no longer support her
                                expenses? Has he
                            no plot on foot against the old gentleman?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: He is a stupid fellow.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Then you ought to assist him--for the sake of the young man.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
For my part, I can do so easily, if you command me; for I know well in
                            what fashion it is usually done.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So much the better, i' faith.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: 'Tis not my way to tell an untruth.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do it then.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
But hark you! Just take care and remember this, in case any thing of
                            this sort should perchance happen at a future time, such are human
                            affairs!--your son might do the same.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The necessity will not arise, I trust.

lemma.#text:
But in
                                    case, none the more

note.#text:
: " Sed si quid, ne quid." An
                                instance of Aposiopesis, signifying "But if any thing does happen,
                                don't you blame me."

: Some suppose that this is said in
                                apparent candor by Syrus, in order the more readily to throw Chremes
                                off his guard. Other Commentators, again, fancy these words to be
                                said by Syrus in a low voice, aside, which seems not improbable; it
                                being a just retribution on Chremes for his recommendation, however
                                well intended: in that case, Chremes probably overhears it, if we
                                may judge from his answer.

p.#text:
I' faith, and I trust so too: nor do I say so now, because I have
                            suspected him in any way; but in case, none the more----You see what his age is;
                                 and truly, Chremes, if an occasion does happen, I may
                            be able to handle you right handsomely.

As to that, we'll consider what is requisite when the occasion does
                            happen. At present do you set about this matter.

Never on any occasion did I hear my master
                            talk more to the purpose; nor at any time could I believe that I was
                            authorized to play the rogue with greater impunity. I wonder who it is
                            coming out of our house?

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES and CLITIPHO from the house of the former.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Pray, what does this mean? What behavior is this, Clitipho? Is this
                            acting as becomes you?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What have I done;

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Did I not see you just now putting your hand into this Courtesan's bosom
                            ?

p.#text: It's all up with us--I'm utterly undone!

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
With these self-same eyes I saw it----don't deny it. Besides, you wrong
                            him unworthily in not keeping your hands off: for indeed it is a gross
                            affront to entertain a person, your friend, at your house, and to take
                            liberties with his mistress. Yesterday, for instance, at wine, how rude
                            you were----

note.#text:
:
                                "Factum." "Done for" is another translation which this word will
                                here admit of.

p.#text: 'Tis the truth

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
How annoying you were So much so, that for my part, as the Gods may
                            prosper me, I dreaded what in the end might be the consequence. I
                            understand lovers. They resent highly things that you would not
                            imagine.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p:
But he has full confidence in me, father, that I would not do any thing
                            of that kind.

note.#text: : Clinia.

p.#text:
Be it so; still, at least, you ought to go somewhere for a little time
                            away from their presence. Passion prompts to many a thing; your presence
                            acts as a restraint upon doing them. I form a judgment from myself.
                            There's not one of my friends this day to whom I would venture,
                            Clitipho, to disclose all my secrets. With one, his station forbids it;
                            with another, I am ashamed of the action itself, lest I may appear a
                            fool or devoid of shame; do you rest assured that he does the
                                same. But
                            it is our part to be sensible of this; and, when and where it is
                            requisite, to show due complaisance.

p.stage: coming forward and whispering to CLITIPHO.
p.#text:
What is it he
                            is saying ?
I'm utterly undone!

lemma.#text:
Of a prudent and discreet
                                    person

note.#text: : This is said ironically.

p.#text:
Clitipho, these same injunctions I gave you. You have acted the part of
                            a prudent and discreet person.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Hold your tongue, I beg.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Very good.

p.#text: Syrus, I am ashamed of him.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I believe it; and not without reason. Why, he vexes myself even.

p.#text: Do you persist, then ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I'm saying the truth, as it appears to me.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: May I not go near them?

note.#text: : And that an immodest one.

p.#text:
How now--pray, is there but one way of going near them
                            ?

Confusion! He'll be betraying himself before I've
                            got the money.  Chremes, will you give attention to
                            me, who am but a silly person?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Bid him go somewhere out of the way.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Where am I to go ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Where you please; leave the place to them; be off and take a walk.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Take a walk! where ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Pshaw! Just as if there was no place to walk in. Why, then, go this way,
                            that way, where you will.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: He says right, I'm of his opinion.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: May the Gods extirpate you, Syrus, for thrusting me away from here.

p.#text:
Then do you for the future keep those
                            hands of yours within bounds.  Really now
                                , what do you think? What do you imagine
                            will become of him next, unless, so far as the Gods afford you the
                            means, you watch him, correct and admonish him ?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll take care of that.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But now, master, he must be looked after by you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: If you are wise,--for now he minds me less and less every day.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
What say you? What have you done, Syrus, about that matter which I was
                            mentioning to you a short time since? Have you any plan that suits you,
                            or not yet even ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
You mean the design upon Menedemus? I have; I have just hit upon
                            one.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You are a clever fellow; what is it? Tell me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I'll tell you; but, as one matter arises out of another----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, what. is it, Syrus?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: This Courtesan is a very bad woman.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So she seems.

p.#text:
Aye, if you did but know. O shocking! just see what she is hatching.
                            There was a certain old woman here from ,--this Bacchis lent her a thousand silver
                            drachmae.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
She is now dead: she has left a daughter, a young girl. She has been
                            left with this Bacchis as a pledge for that sum.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I understand you.

note.#text:
: Madame Dacier
                                remarks, that as Anitiphila is shortly to be acknowledged as the
                                daughter of Chremes, she is not therefore in company with the other
                                women at the feast, who arc Courtesans, but with the wife of
                                Chremes, and consequently free from reproach or scandal.

p.#text:
She has brought her hither along with her, her I mean who is now with
                            your wife.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
She is soliciting Clinia at once to advance her this money; she says,
                            however, that this girl is to be a security, that, at a future time, she
                            will repay the thousand pieces of money.

lemma.#text:
Would she really be a
                                    security

note.#text:
: The question of Chremes seems directed to the
                                fact whether the girl is of value sufficient to be good security for
                                the thousand drachmae.

p.#text: And would she really be a security ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Dear me, is it to be doubted ? I think so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then do you intend doing?

p.#text:
What, I? I shall go to Menedemus; I'll tell him she is a captive from
                                , rich, and of noble
                            family; if he redeems her, there will be a considerable profit in this
                            transaction.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You are in an error.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why so ?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll now answer you for Menedemus--I will not purchase her.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What is it you say? Do speak more agreeably to our wishes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But there is no occasion.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: No occasion?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Certainly not, i' faith.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: How so, I wonder?

note.#text:
:
                                Madame Dacier suggests that Chremes is prevented by his wife's
                                coming from making a proposal to advance the money himself, on the
                                supposition that it will be a lucrative speculation. This notion is
                                contradicted by Colman, who adds the following note from Eugraphius:
                                "Syrus pretends to have concerted this plot against Menedemus, in
                                order to trick him out of some money to be given to Clinia's
                                supposed mistress. Chremes, however, does not approve of this: yet
                                it serves to carry on the plot; for when Antiphila proves afterward
                                to be the daughter of Chremes, he necessarily becomes the debtor of
                                Bacchis, and is obliged to lay down the sum for which he imagines
                                his daughter is pledged."

p.#text: You shall soon know.

Stop, stop; what is the reason that there is such a great noise at our
                            door ?

p:
Enter SOSTRATA and a NURSE in haste from the house of CHREMES, and CHREMES
                        and SYRUS on the other side of the stage unperceived.

p.stage: holding up a ring and examining it.
p.#text:
Sos.  Unless my fancy
                        deceives me, surely this is the ring which I suspect it to be, the same with
                        which my daughter was exposed.

Syrus, what is the meaning of these expressions
                            ?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Nurse, how is it? Does it not seem to you the same?

sp.speaker: NUR.
sp.p:
As for me, I said it was the same the very instant that you showed it
                            me.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: But have you now examined it thoroughly, my dear nurse?

sp.speaker: NUR.
sp.p: Thoroughly.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
Then go in-doors at once, and if she has now done bathing, bring me
                            word. I'll wait here in the mean time for my husband.

p.#text:
She wants you, see what it is she wants; she is in
                            a serious mood, I don't know why; it is not without a cause----I fear
                            what it may be.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
What it may be? I' faith, she'll now surely be announcing some important
                            trifle, with a great parade.

p.#text: Ha! my husband!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ha! my wife !

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I was looking for you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
In the first place, this I beg of you, not to believe that I have
                            ventured to do any thing contrary to your commands.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Would you have me believe you in this, although so incredible? Well, I
                            will believe you.

p.#text: This excuse portends I know not what offense.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
Do you remember me being pregnant, and yourself declaring to me, most
                            peremptorily, that if I should bring forth a girl, you would not have it
                            brought up.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I know what you have done, you have brought it up.

note.#text:
: He alludes to
                                Clitipho, who, by the discovery of his sister, would not come in for
                                such a large share of his father's property, and would consequently,
                                as Syrus observes, gain a loss.

p.#text:
Such is the fact, I'm sure: my young master has
                            gained a loss in consequence.

Not at all; but there was here an elderly woman of , of no indifferent character;
                            to her I gave it to be exposed.

O ! that there should be
                            such extreme folly in a person's mind.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Alas! what have I done ?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: And do you ask the question?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: If I have acted wrong, my dear Chremes, I have done so in ignorance.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
This, indeed, I know for certain, even if you were to deny it, that in
                            every thing you both speak and act ignorantly and foolishly: how many
                            blunders you disclose in this single affair! For, in the first place,
                            then, if you had been disposed to obey my orders, the child ought to
                            have been dispatched; you ought not in words to have feigned her death,
                            and in reality to have left hopes of her surviving. But that I pass
                            over; compassion, maternal affection, I allow it. But how finely you did
                            provide for the future! What was your meaning ? Do reflect. It's clear,
                            beyond a doubt, that your daughter was betrayed by you to this old
                            woman, either that through you she might make a living by her, or that
                            she might be sold in open market as a slave. I suppose you reasoned
                            thus: " any thing is enough, if only her life is saved :" what are you
                            to do with those who understand neither law, nor right and justice? Be
                            it for better or for worse, be it for them or against them, they see
                            nothing except just what they please.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
My dear Chremes, I have done wrong, I own ; I am convinced. Now this I
                            beg of you; inasmuch as you are more advanced in years than I, be so
                            much the more ready to forgive; so that your justice may be some
                            protection for my weakness.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
I'll readily forgive you doing this, of course; but, Sostrata, my easy
                            temper prompts you to do amiss. But, whatever this circumstance is, by
                            reason of which this was begun upon, proceed to tell it.

note.#text:
That she
                                might not be without)--Ver 652. Madame Dacier observes upon this
                                passage, that the ancients thought themselves guilty of a heinous
                                offense if they suffered their children to die without having
                                bestowed on them some of their property; it was consequently the
                                custom of the women, before exposing children, to attach to them
                                some jewel or trinket among their clothes, hoping thereby to avoid
                                incurring the guilt above mentioned, and to ease their
                                consciences.

p.#text:
As we women are all foolishly and wretchedly superstitious, when I
                            delivered the child to her to be exposed, I drew a ring from off my
                            finger, and ordered her to expose it, together with the child; that if
                            she should die, she might not be without some portion of our possessions.

note.#text:
: Madame Dacier
                                says that the meaning of this passage is this: Chremes tells his
                                wife that by having given this ring, she has done two good acts
                                instead of one--she has both cleared her conscience and saved the
                                child; for had there been no ring or token exposed with the infant,
                                the finder would not have been at the trouble of taking care of it,
                                but might have left it to perish, never suspecting it would be
                                inquired after, or himself liberally rewarded for having preserved
                                it.

p.#text:
That was right; thereby you proved the saving of yourself and
                                her.
This is that ring.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Whence did you get it?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: From the young woman whom Bacchis brought here with her.

p.#text: Ha!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What does she say?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
She gave it me to keep for her, while she went to bathe. At first I paid
                            no attention to it; but after I looked at it, I at once recognized it,
                            and came running to you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you suspect now, or have you discovered, relative to her ?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
I don't know; unless you inquire of herself whence she got it, if that
                            can possibly be discovered.

note.#text:
: Syrus is now alarmed that Antiphila should
                                so soon be acknowledged as the daughter of Chremes, lest he may lose
                                the opportunity of obtaining the money, and be punished as well, in
                                case the imposition is detected, and Bacchis discovered to be the
                                mistress of Clitipho and not of Clinia.

p.#text:
I'm undone! I see more hopes from this incident
                            than I desire. If it is so, she certainly must be ours.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Is this woman living to whom you delivered the child?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What account did she bring you at the time?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: That she had done as I had ordered her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what is the woman's name, that she may be inquired after.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Philtere.

p.#text:
'Tis the very same. It's a wonder if she isn't
                            found, and I lost.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Sostrata, follow me this way in-doors.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p:
How much beyond my hopes has this matter turned out! How dreadfully
                            afraid I was, Chremes, that you would now be of feelings as unrelenting
                            as formerly you were on exposing the child.

note.#text:
: This
                                he says by way of palliating the cruelty he was guilty of in his
                                orders to have the child put to death.

p.stage: CHREMES and SOSTRATA go into the house.)

div2.stage: SYRUS alone.

note.#text:
: "Nisi me animus fallit." He comically repeats the
                                very same words with which Sostrata commenced in the last
                                Scene.

:
                                "Infortunium!" was the name by which the slaves commonly denoted a
                                beating. Colman has the following remark here: " Madame Dacier, and
                                most of the later critics who have implicitly followed her, tell us
                                that in the interval between the third and fourth Acts, Syrus has
                                been present at the interview between Chremes and Antiphila within.
                                The only difficulty in this doctrine is how to reconcile it to the
                                apparent ignorance of Syrus, which he discovers at the entrance of
                                Clinia. But this objection, says she, is easily answered. Syrus
                                having partly heard Antiphila's story, and finding things likely to
                                take an unfavorable turn, retires, to consider what is best to be
                                done. But surely this is a most unnatural impatience at so critical
                                a conjuncture; and, after all, would it not be better to take up the
                                matter just where Terence has left it, and to suppose that Syrus
                                knew nothing more of the affair than what might be collected from
                                the late conversation between Chremes and Sostrata, at which we know
                                he was present ? This at once accounts for his apprehensions, which
                                he betrayed even during that Scene, as well as for his imperfect
                                knowledge of the real state of the case, till apprised of the whole
                                by Clinia."

: He most
                                probably alludes to the custom of tying up the slaves by their
                                hands, after stripping them naked, when of course their " latera" or
                                " sides" would be exposed, and come in for a share of the
                                lashes.

: "Fugitivum
                                argentum." Madame Dacier suggests that this is a bad translation of
                                the words of Menander, which were "" where "
                                    "" signified both " gold"
                                and the name of a slave.

p.#text:
Unless my fancy deceives me, retribution will not be very far off from me; so much by this
                            incident are my forces now utterly driven into straits; unless I
                            contrive by some means that the old man mayn't come to know that this
                            damsel is his son's mistress. For as to entertaining any hopes about the
                            money, or supposing I could cajole him, it's useless; I shall be
                            sufficient triumphant, if I'm allowed to escape with my sides
                                covered. I'm vexed that such a tempting morsel has been so
                            suddenly snatched away from my jaws. What am I to do? Or what shall I
                            devise? I must begin upon my plan over again. Nothing is so difficult,
                            but that it may be found out by seeking. What now if I set about it
                            after this fashion.  That's of no use. What,
                            if after this fashion? I effect just about the same. But this I think
                            will do. It can not. Yes! excellent. Bravo! I've found out the best of
                            all--I' faith, I do believe that after all I shall lay hold of this same
                            run-away money.

div2.stage: Enter CLINIA at the other side of the stage.

p.#text:
Nothing can possibly henceforth befall me of
                            such consequence as to cause me uneasiness; so extreme is this joy that
                            has surprised me. Now then I shall give myself up entirely to my father,
                            to be more frugal than even he could wish.

I wasn't mistaken; she has been discovered, so far
                            as I understand from these words of his.  I am
                            rejoiced that this matter has turned out for you so much to your
                            wish.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: O my dear Syrus, have you heard of it, pray?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: How shouldn't I, when I was present all the while ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
Did you ever hear of any thing falling out so fortunately for any
                            one?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
And, so may the Gods prosper me, I do not now rejoice so much on my own
                            account as hers, whom I know to be deserving of any honor.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
I believe it: but now, Clinia, come, attend to me in my turn. For your
                            friend's business as well,--it must be seen to--that it is placed in a
                            state of security, lest the old gentleman should now come to know any
                            thing about his mistress.

p.#text: O !

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Do be quiet.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: My Antiphila will be mine.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Do you still interrupt me thus ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
What can I do? My dear Syrus, I'm transported with joy! Do bear with
                            me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I really do bear with you.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: We are blest with the life of the Gods.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I'm taking pains to no purpose, I doubt.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Speak; I hear you.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But still you'll not mind it.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
This must be seen to, I say, that your friend's business as well is
                            placed in a state of security. For if you now go away from us, and leave
                            Bacchis here, our old man will immediately come to know that she is
                            Clitipho's mistress; if you take her away with you, it will be concealed
                            just as much as it has been hitherto concealed.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
SYRUS
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What can I say? What excuse can I make?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Nay, I don't want you to dissemble; tell him the whole case just as it
                            really is.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What is it you say ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
I bid you do this; tell him that you are in love with her, and want her
                            for a wife: that this Bacchis is Clitipho's mistress.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
You require a thing that is fair and reasonable, and easy to be done.
                            And I suppose, then, you would have me request my father to keep it a
                            secret from your old man.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On the contrary; to tell him directly the matter just as it is.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
What? Are you quite in your senses or sober? Why, you were for ruining
                            him outright. For how could he be in a state of security ? Tell me
                            that.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
For my part, I yield the palm to this device. Here I do pride myself
                            exultingly, in having in myself such exquisite resources, and power of
                            address so great, as to deceive them both by telling the truth: so that
                            when your old man tells ours that she is his son's mistress, he'll still
                            not believe him.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
But yet, by these means you again cut off all hopes of my marriage; for
                            as long as Chremes believes that she is my mistress, he'll not give me
                            his daughter. Perhaps you care little what becomes of me, so long as you
                            provide for him.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
What the plague, do you suppose I want this pretense to be kept up for
                            an age ? 'Tis but for a single day, only till I have secured the money:
                            you be quiet; I ask no more.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p:
Is that sufficient? If his father should come to know of it, pray, what
                            then?

lemma.#text: If the sky were to fall

note.#text:
: He means
                                those who create unnecessary difficulties in their imagination.
                                Colman quotes the following remark from Patrick: "There is a
                                remarkable passage in Arrian's Account of Alexander, lib. iv., where
                                he tells us that some embassadors from the Celtae, being asked by
                                Alexander what in the world they dreaded most, answered, ' That they
                                feared lest the sky should fall [upon them].' Alexander, who
                                expected to hear himself named, was surprised at an answer which
                                signified that they thought themselves beyond the reach of all human
                                power, plainly implying that nothing could hurt them, unless he
                                would suppose impossibilities, or a total destruction of nature."
                                Aristotle, in his Physics, B. iv., informs us that it was the early
                                notion of ignorant nations that the sky was supported on the
                                shoulders of Atlas, and that when he let go of it, it would
                                fall.

p.#text:
What if I have recourse to those who say, " What now if the sky were to
                                fall?"

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: I'm afraid to go about it.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
You, afraid! As if it was not in your power to clear yourself at any
                            time you like, and discover the whole matter.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Well, well; let Bacchis be brought over to our house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Capital! she is coming out of doors.

div2.stage:
Enter BACCHIS and PHRYGIA, from
                        the house of CHREMES.

p.stage: pretending not to see CLINIA and SYRUS.

note.#text:
: " Satis
                                pol proterve," &c. C. Laelius was said to have assisted
                                Terence in the composition of his Plays, and in confirmation of
                                this, the following story is told by Cornelius Nepos: " C. Laelius,
                                happening to pass the Matronalia [a Festival on the first of March,
                                when the husband, for once in the year, was bound to obey the wife]
                                at his villa near , was told that dinner was waiting, but
                                still neglected the summons. At last, when he made his appearance,
                                he excused himself by saying that he had been in a particular vein
                                of composition, and quoted certain lines which occur in the
                                Heautontimorumenos, namely, those beginning ' Satis pol proterve me
                                Syri promissa hue induxerunt.'"

p.#text:
To a very fine
                                purpose, upon my faith, have the
                            promises of Syrus brought me hither, who agreed to lend me ten minae. If
                            now he deceives me, oft as he may entreat me to come, he shall come in
                            vain. Or else, when I've promised to come, and fixed the time, when he
                            has carried word back for certain, and Clitipho is on the stretch of
                            expectation, I'll disappoint him and not come. Syrus will make atonement
                            to me with his back.
She promises you very fairly.

But do you think she is in jest? She'll do it,
                            if I don't take care.

note.#text:
:
                                "Dormiunt." This is clearly used figuratively, though Hedelin
                                interprets it literally.

p.#text:
They're asleep--I'faith, I'll rouse them.
                                 My dear Phrygia, did you hear about the country-seat of
                            Charinus, which that man was showing us just now ?

sp.speaker: PHRYGIA
sp.p: I heard of it.

lemma.#text: Farm here on the right-hand side

note.#text:
:
                                Cooke suggests that the Poet makes Bacchis call the house of
                                Charinus "villa," and that of Chremes "fundus" (which signifies " a
                                farm-house," or "farm"), for the purpose of exalting the one and
                                depreciating the other in the hearing of Syrus.

p.#text:
That it was the next to the farm here on the
                            right-hand side.

sp.speaker: PHRYGIA
sp.p: I remember.

note.#text:
: This passage goes far to prove
                                that the Dionysia here mentioned as being celebrated, were those
                                     or the " rural
                                Dionysia."

p.#text:
Run thither post-haste; the Captain is keeping the
                            feast of  at his house.
What is she going to be at?

Tell him I am here very much against my
                            inclination, and am detained; but that by some means or other I'll give
                            them the slip and come to him.

Upon my faith, I'm ruined! Bacchis, stay,
                            stay; prithee, where are you sending her ? Order her to stop.
Be off.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why, the money's ready.

p.#text: Why, then I'll stay.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: And it will be given you presently.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Just when you please; do I press you ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But do you know what you are to do, pray?

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
You must now go over to the house of Menedemus, and your equipage must
                            be taken over thither.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: What scheme are you upon, you rascal?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What, I ? Coining money to give you.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Do you think me a proper person for you to play upon ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It's not without a purpose.

p.#text:
Why, have I any business then with
                            you here?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: O no; I'm only going to give you what's your own.

note.#text:
:
                                    Colman here remarks to
                                the following effect: "There is some difficulty in this and the next
                                speech in the original, and the Commentators have been puzzled to
                                make sense of them. It seems to me that the Poet's intention is no
                                more than this: Bacchis expresses some reluctance to act under the
                                direction of Syrus, but is at length prevailed on, finding that he
                                can by those means contrive to pay her the money which he has
                                promised her."

p.#text: Then let's be going.

stage:
Goes to the door of MENEDIEMUS, and
                                calls.
p.#text: Follow this way.  Ho there! Dromo.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: Who is it wants me ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Syrus.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Take over all the attendants of Bacchis to your house here
                            immediately.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Ask no questions. Let them take what they brought here with them. The
                            old gentleman will hope his expenses are lightened by their departure;
                            for sure he little knows how much loss this trifling gain will bring
                            him. You, Dromo, if you are wise, know nothing of what you do know.

p.stage:
CLINIA, BACCHIS, and PHRYGIA go into
                                the house of MENEDEMUS, and DROMO follows with BACCHIS'S retinue and
                                baggage.
p.#text: You shall own that I'm dumb.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES from his house.

p.#text:
So may the Deities prosper me, I am now
                            concerned for the fate of Menedemus, that so great a misfortune should
                            have befallen him. To be maintaining that woman with such a retinue!
                            Although I am well aware he'll not be sensible of it for some days to
                            come, his son was so greatly missed by him; but when he sees such a vast
                            expense incurred by him every day at home, and no limit to it, he'll
                            wish that this son would leave him a second time. See--here comes Syrus
                            most opportunely.

p.stage: to himself, as he comes forward.
p.#text:
Why delay to accost
                            him?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Syrus.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How go matters ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I've been wishing for some time for you to be thrown in my way.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
YOU seem, then, to have effected something, I know not what, with the
                            old gentleman.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
As to what we were talking of a short time since? No sooner said than
                            done.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: In real earnest ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: In real.

p.#text:
Upon my faith, I can not forbear patting your head for it. Come here,
                            Syrus; I'll do you some good turn for this matter, and with pleasure.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But if you knew how cleverly it came into my head----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Pshaw! Do you boast because it has turned out according to your
                            wishes

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On my word, not I, indeed; I am telling the truth.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me how it is.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Clinia has told Menedemus, that this Bacchis is your Clitipho's
                            mistress, and that he has taken her thither with him in order that you
                            might not come to know of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Tell me, please, what you think of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Extremely good, I declare.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Why yes, pretty fair. But listen, what a piece of policy still remains.
                            He is then to say that he has seen your daughter--that her beauty
                            charmed him as soon as he beheld her; and that he desires her for a
                            wife.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What, her that has just been discovered ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: The same; and, in fact, he'll request that she may be asked for.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what purpose, Syrus? For I don't altogether comprehend it.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: O dear, you are so dull.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Money will be given him for the wedding--with which golden trinkets and
                            clothes----do you understand me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To buy them----?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But I neither give nor betroth my daughter to him.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, do you ask me? To a fellow----

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Just as you please. I don't mean that in reality you should give her to
                            him, but that you should pretend it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Pretending is not in my way; do you mix up these plots of yours, so as
                            not to mix me up in them. Do you think that I'll betroth my daughter to
                            a person to whom I will not marry her?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I imagined so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
It might have been cleverly managed; and I under-took this affair for
                            the very reason, that a short time since you so urgently requested
                            it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But for my part, Chremes, I take it well and good, either way.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
But still, I especially wish you to do your best for it to be brought
                            about; but in some other way.

note.#text:
:  mentions the same proverb in his work De
                                Officiis, B. i., ch. 10, substituting the word "injuria" for "
                                malitia." "' Extreme law, extreme injustice,' is now become a stale
                                proverb in discourse." The same sentiment is found in the Fragments
                                of Menander.

p.#text:
It shall be done: some other method must be thought of; but as to what I
                            was telling you of,--about the money which she owes to Bacchis,--that
                            must now be repaid her. And you will not, of course, now be having
                            recourse to this method; "What have I to do with it? Was it lent to me?
                            Did I give any orders? Had she the power to pawn my daughter without my
                            consent?" They quote that saying, Chremes, with good reason, " Riorous
                                law is often rigorous injustice."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I will not do so.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
On the contrary, though others were at liberty, you are not at liberty;
                            all think that you are in good and very easy circumstances.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nay rather, I'll at once carry it to her myself.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why no; request your son in preference.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Why, because the suspicion of being in love with her has been
                            transferred to him with Menedemus.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS

p.#text: I'll bring it.

div2.stage: Enter CLITIPHO.

p.#text:
There is nothing so easy but that it becomes
                            difficult when you do it with reluctance. As this walk of mine, for
                            instance, though not fatiguing, it has reduced me to weariness. And now
                            I dread nothing more than that I should be packed off somewhere hence
                            once again, that I may not have access to Bacchis. May then all the Gods
                            and Goddesses, as many as exist, confound you, Syrus, with these
                            stratagems and plots of yours. You are always devising something of this
                            kind, by means of which to torture me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Will you not away with you--to where you deserve? How nearly had your
                            forwardness proved my ruin!

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Upon my faith, I wish it had been so; just what you deserve.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Deserve? How so? Really, I'm glad that I've heard this from you before
                            you had the money which I was just going to give you.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p:
What then would you have me to say to you? You've made a fool of me;
                            brought my mistress hither, whom I'm not allowed to touch----

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Well, I'm not angry then. But do you know where Bacchis is just now?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: At our house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: At Clinia's.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I'm ruined!

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
Be of good heart; you shall presently carry to her the money that you
                            promised her.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: You do prate away.--Where from?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: From your own father.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Perhaps you are joking with me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: The thing itself will prove it.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Indeed, then, I am a lucky man. Syrus, I do love you from my heart.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p:
But your father's coming out. Take care not to express surprise at any
                            thing, for what reason it is done; give way at the proper moment; do
                            what he orders, and say but little.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES from the house, with a bag of money.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Where's Clitipho now?

p.#text: Say--here I am.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Here am I.

p.#text: Have you told him how it is?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I've told him pretty well every thing.

p.#text: Take this money, and carry it.

Go--why do you stand still, you stone;
                            why don't you take it?
Very well, give it me.

stage:
CLITIPHO and SYRUS go into the house of
                            MENEDEMUS.
p.#text:
Follow me this way directly.  You in the mean while will wait here for us till we
                            return; for there's no occasion for us to stay there long.

note.#text:
: He
                                inveighs, perhaps justly, against the tyranny of custom; but in
                                selecting this occasion for doing so, he does not manifest any great
                                affection for his newly-found daughter.

p.#text:
My daughter, in fact, has now had ten minae
                            from me, which I consider as paid for her board; another ten will follow
                            these for clothes; and then she will require two talents for her
                            portion. How many things, both just and unjust, are sanctioned by
                                custom! Now I'm obliged,
                            neglecting my business, to look out for some one on whom to bestow my
                            property, that has been acquired by my labor.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS from his house.

p.#text:
My son, I now think myself the happiest
                            of all men, since I find that you have returned to a rational mode of
                            life.
How much he is mistaken!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Chremes, you are the very person I wanted; preserve, so far as in you
                            lies, my son, myself, and my family.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what you would have me do.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: You have this day found a daughter.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Clinia wishes her to be given him for a wife.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Prithee, what kind of a person are you?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Have you already forgotten what passed between us, concerning a scheme,
                            that by that method some money might be got out of you?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That self-same thing they are now about.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
What do you tell me, Chremes? Why surely, this Courtesan, who is at my
                            house, is Clitipho's mistress.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
So they say, and you believe it all; and they say that he is desirous of
                            a wife, in order that, when I have betrothed her, you may give him
                            money, with which to provide gold trinkets and clothing, and other
                            things that are requisite.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: That is it, no doubt; that money will be given to his mistress.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Of course it is to be given.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Alas! in vain then, unhappy man, have I been overjoyed; still however, I
                            had rather any thing than be deprived of him. What answer now shall I
                            report from you, Chremes, so that he may not perceive that I have found
                            it out, and take it to heart?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To heart, indeed! you are too indulgent to him, Menedemus.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Let me go on; I have now begun: assist me in this throughout,
                            Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Say then, that you have seen me, and have treated about the
                            marriage.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I'll say so--what then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
That I will do every thing; that as a son-in-law he meets my
                            approbation; in fine, too, if you like, tell him also that she has been
                            promised him.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Well, that's what I wanted----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
That he may the sooner ask of you, and you may as soon as possible give
                            him what you wish.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: It is my wish.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Assuredly, before very long, according as I view this matter, you'll
                            have enough of him. But, however that may be, if you are wise, you'll
                            give to him cautiously, and a little at a time.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Go in-doors and see how much he requires. I shall be at home, if you
                            should want me for any thing.

p.stage: They go into their respective houses.
p.#text: I certainly do want you; for I shall let you know whatever I do.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS from his house.

stage:
Enter
                                CHREMES, speaking to SOSTRATA within.

note.#text:
:
                                The three terms here used are borrowed from the stage. "Adjutor" was
                                the person who assisted the performers either by voice or gesture;
                                "monitor" was the prompter; and "praemonstrator" was the person who
                                in the rehearsal trained the actor in his part.

: There is a similar passage in the
                                Bacchides of Plautus, 1. 1087. "Whoever there are in any place
                                whatsoever, whoever have been, and whoever shall be in time to come,
                                fools, blockheads, idiots, dolts, sots, oafs, lubbers, I singly by
                                far exceed them all in folly and absurd ways."

p.#text:
I am quite aware that I am not so overwise,
                            or so very quick-sighted; but this assistant, prompter, and
                                director of mine,
                            Chremes, outdoes me in that. Any one of those epithets which are applied
                            to a fool is suited to myself, such as dolt, post, ass, lump of lead;
                            to him not one can apply; his stupidity surpasses them all.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Hold now, do, wife, leave off dinning the Gods with thanksgivings that
                            your daughter has been discovered; unless you judge of them by your own
                            disposition, and think that they understand nothing, unless the same
                            thing has been told them a hundred times. But, in the mean time, why
                            does my son linger there so long with Syrus?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What persons do you say are lingering?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Ha! Menedemus, you have come opportunely. Tell me, have you told Clinia
                            what I said?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Every thing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: He began to rejoice, just like people do who wish to be married.

p.#text: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why are you laughing?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The sly tricks of my servant, Syrus, just came into my mind.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Did they?

note.#text:
Mould the countenances of people--Ver. 887. He means that Syrus not
                                only lays his plots well, but teaches the performers to put on
                                countenances suitable to the several parts they are to
                            act.

p.#text: The rogue can even mould the countenances of people.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: That my son is pretending that he is overjoyed, is it that you mean?

p.#text: Just so.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: The very same thing came into my mind.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: A crafty knave!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Still more would you think such to be the fact, if you knew more.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you say so?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Do you give attention then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Just stop--first I want to know this, what money you have squandered;
                            for when you told your son that she was promised, of course Dromo would
                            at once throw in a word that golden jewels, clothes, and attendants
                            would be needed for the bride, in order that you might give the
                            money.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How, no?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No, I tell you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nor yet your son himself?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Not in the slightest, Chremes. He was only the more pressing on this one
                            point, that the match might be concluded to-day.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
You say what's surprising. What did my servant Syrus do? Didn't even he
                            say any thing?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what reason, I don't know.

note.#text:
: "Mire finxit." He sarcastically uses the same word,
                                "fingo," which Chremes himself employed in 1. 887.

p.#text:
For my part, I wonder at that, when you know other things so well. But
                            this same Syrus has moulded your son, too, to
                            such perfection, that there could not be even the slightest suspicion
                            that she is Clinia's mistress!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Not to mention, then, their kissing and embracing; that I count
                            nothing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What more could be done to carry on the cheat?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Only listen. In the inner part of my house there is a certain room at
                            the back; into this a bed was brought, and was made up with
                            bed-clothes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What took place after this?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No sooner said than done, thither went Clitipho.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Alone.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm alarmed.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Bacchis followed directly.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Alone.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: When they had gone into the room, they shut the door.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Well--did Clinia see all this going on?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: How shouldn't he? He was with me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Bacchis is my son's mistress, Menedemus I'm undone.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why so?

lemma.#text:
Substance
                                    to suffice for ten days

note.#text:
: "Familia" here means
                                "property," as producing sustenance. Colman, however, has translated the passage: "Mine
                                is scarce a ten-days' family."

p.#text: I have hardly substance to suffice for ten days.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
What! are you alarmed at it, because he is paying attention to his
                            friend?

note.#text:
:
                                Menedemus speaks of "amico," a male friend, which Chremes plays upon
                                by saying amicae," which literally meant a she-friend, and was the
                                usual name by which decent people called a mistress.

p.#text: His "she-friend" rather.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: If he really is paying it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Is it a matter of doubt to you? Do you suppose that there is any person
                            of so accommodating and tame a spirit as to suffer his own mistress,
                            himself looking on, to----

p.#text:
Why not? That I may be
                            imposed upon the more easily.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Do you laugh at me? You have good reason. How angry I now am with
                            myself! How many things gave proof, whereby, had I not been a stone, I
                            might have been fully sensible of this? What was it I saw? Alas! wretch
                            that I am! But assuredly they shall not escape my vengeance if I live;
                            for this instant----

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Can you not contain yourself? Have you no respect for yourself? Am I not
                            a sufficient example to you?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For very anger, Menedemus, I am not myself.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
For you to talk in that manner! Is it not a shame for you to be giving
                            advice to others, to show wisdom abroad and yet be able to do nothing
                            for yourself?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What shall I do?

note.#text:
: Madame Dacier observes
                                here, that one of the great beauties of this Scene consists in
                                Chremes retorting on Menedemus the very advice given by himself at
                                the beginning of the Play.

p.#text:
That which you said I failed to do: make him sensible that you are his
                            father; make him venture to intrust every thing to you, to seek and to
                            ask of you; so that he may look for no other resources and forsake
                                you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Nay, I had much rather he would go any where in the world, than by his
                            debaucheries here reduce his father to beggary! For if I go on supplying
                            his extravagance, Menedemus, in that case my circumstances will
                            undoubtedly be soon reduced to the level of your rake.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
CHREMES
sp.p: Ah! you don't know how vexed I am.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Just as you please. What about that which I desire--that she may be
                            married to my son? Unless there is any other step that you would
                            prefer.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
On the contrary, both the son-in-law and the connection are to my
                            taste.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
What portion shall I say that you have named for your daughter? Why are
                            you silent?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Portion?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I say so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
Chremes, don't be at all afraid to speak, if it is but a small one. The
                            portion is no consideration at all with us.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
I did think that two talents were sufficient, according to my means. But
                            if you wish me to be saved, and my estate and my son, you must say to
                            this effect, that I have settled all my property on her as her
                            portion.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What scheme are you upon?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Pretend that you wonder at this, and at the same time ask him the reason
                            why I do so.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why, really, I can't conceive the reason for your doing so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Why do I do so? To check his feelings, which are now hurried away by
                            luxury and wantonness, and to bring him down so as not to know which way
                            to turn himself.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What is your design?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Let me alone, and give me leave to have my own way in this matter.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I do give you leave: is this your desire

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Then be it so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
And now let your son prepare to fetch the bride. The other one shall be
                            schooled in such language as befits children. But Syrus----

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What of him?

lemma.#text: Which he has done to me

note.#text:
:
                                    Colman has the
                                following Note: "The departure of Menedemus here is very abrupt,
                                seeming to be in the midst of a conversation; and his re-entrance
                                with Clitipho, already supposed to be apprised of what has passed
                                between the two old gentlemen, is equally precipitate. Menage
                                imagines that some verses are lost here. Madame Dacier strains hard
                                to defend the Poet, and fills up the void of time by her old
                                expedient of making the Audience wait to see Chremes walk
                                impatiently to and fro, till a sufficient time is elapsed for
                                Menedemus to have given Clitipho a summary account of the cause of
                                his father's anger. The truth is, that a too strict observance of
                                the unity of place will necessarily produce such absurdities; and
                                there are several other instances of the like nature in
                                Terence."

p.stage: They go into their respective houses.
p.#text:
What? If I live, I will have him so handsomely dressed, so well combed
                            out, that he shall always remember me as long as he lives; to imagine
                            that I'm to be a laughing-stock and a plaything for him! So may the Gods
                            bless me! he would not have dared to do to a widow-woman the things
                            which he has done to me.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS, with CLITIPHO and SYRUS.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p:
Prithee, is it really the fact, Menedemus, that my father can, in so
                            short a space of time, have cast off all the natural affection of a
                            parent for me? For what crime? What so great enormity have I, to my
                            misfortune, committed? Young men generally do the same.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p:
I am aware that this must be much more harsh and severe to you, on whom
                            it falls; but yet I take it no less amiss than you. How it is so I know
                            not, nor can I account for it, except that from my heart I wish you
                            well.

p.#text: Did not you say that my father was waiting here?
See, here he is.

note.#text:
: This is an early instance of a
                                trusteeship and a guardianship.

p.#text:
Why are you blaming me, Clitipho? Whatever I have done in this matter, I
                            had a view to you and your imprudence. When I saw that you were of a
                            careless disposition, and held the pleasures of the moment of the first
                            importance, and did not look forward to the future, I took measures that
                            you might neither want nor be able to waste this which I have. When,
                            through your own conduct, it was not allowed me to give it you, to whom
                            I ought before all, I had recourse to those who were your nearest
                            relations; to them I have made over and intrusted every thing. There you'll always find a
                            refuge for your folly; food, clothing, and a roof under which to betake
                            yourself.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
It is better than that, you being my heir, Bacchis should possess this
                            estate of mine.

p.#text:
I'm ruined irrevocably!--Of what mischief have I,
